title: Adam Lallana insists Man Utd equaliser is only start of "big moments" for him at Liverpool this season
text:

Adam Lallana says that his huge goal at Old Trafford is just the start of some big moments for him and Liverpool this season.

The Reds midfielder has endured a bleak period in his career in recent years, with injuries and strong competition in the Anfield squad reducing him to the role of bit part player.

Yet he performed it to perfection against bitter rivals Manchester United , with an equaliser five minutes from time that kept his side’s unbeaten Premier League run going, just as it appeared to be shattered.

That has given Lallana the confidence to believe he will force his way back into Jurgen Klopp’s thinking, and allow him to prove he can play a huge part in success this season.

"I'm delighted. It's obviously nice to contribute to a top team like this - and I feel that's the first of big moments me for this season,” he said.

(Image: Getty Images)

"Just because I've not started any of the first nine games, I don't think that means I am not going to play a big part in this team.

“Can this be my season? Of course, yeah. It's a long old season. We've got the World Club Cup to come. The Champions League this week, the Premier League at the weekend, the Carabao Cup next week.

“So it’s important to stay strong and be ready. That’s where my focus will be and I’m delighted I can make an impact when I get the chance.”

Lallana has unfairly been dismissed as ‘injury prone’ in recent years, but in fact, he has been fit and healthy for the best part of 18 months.

He has struggled to find rhythm though, after struggling for game time in a midfield where even skipper Jordan Henderson is always an automatic starter.

(Image: PA)

The England player has started just one game this season, in the EFL Cup, and made just five Premier League starts during the previous TWO campaigns.

He believes he is back to peak fitness though, and in the right shape to still be an important member of the squad, especially given the demands on players at the top level, which mean inevitable injuries:

"Football's a funny game. The last couple of years, we've got to the Champions League final with a maximum of just four really fit centre midfielders.

“So it's about just staying fit, staying strong and staying ready. I feel that's where my focus will be.

"Listen, obviously I feel like I've been fit for a good year now, especially since coming back from pre-season. But we're European champions, we've got a top squad, so I've had to be patient for my chance.

“I’ve done that, and I am delighted to come on and make an impact like that. We are a top team, so to be able to contribute to it is important.”

Memories are short, and fans seem to have already forgotten just how important Lallana was in Klopp’s thinking during his early years at Liverpool.

The manager said he set the tone for the pressing game, with an intelligence of movement and understanding of the system that the others followed.

He’s been ignored by the supporters, in part, because his goal at Old Trafford was the midfielder’s first for the Reds since May 21 2017, though he admitted he’s found the net a few times since against slightly lesser opposition.

"I've scored plenty in the back garden against my lad since then - didn't feel half as good, though!" he explained.

“I know my boy at home would have been watching and been delighted when that went in, so it’s a big moment.”
description: The Reds midfielder insists this can yet be his season after finding the net at Old Trafford on Sunday
